items.title: Ukraine: Donald Trump urges Volodymyr Zelensky to cut deal with Russia
items.standfirst: Donald Trump urged Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Friday to strike a deal with Russia, dampening Ukraine's hopes for US Tomahawk missiles. Just a month after backing Ukraine’s goal to reclaim all its territory, Trump shifted his stance following an agreement to meet Russian President Vladimir Putin for a new summit. FRANCE 24's Fraser Jackson has more from Washington.
items.content: Donald Trump urged Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Friday to strike a deal with Russia, dampening Ukraine's hopes for US Tomahawk missiles. Just a month after backing Ukraine’s goal to reclaim all its territory, Trump shifted his stance following an agreement to meet Russian President Vladimir Putin for a new summit. FRANCE 24's Fraser Jackson has more from Washington.

items.title: Zelensky ready to join Putin-Trump summit ‘if invited', Ukraine to buy 25 Patriot systems
items.standfirst: Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelensky said he is ready to join Vladimir Putin and Donald Trump in Budapest if he is invited to the Russian and US leaders’ summit. The meeting has been set up by Trump in a bid to broker peace in Ukraine and could be held in a matter of weeks. Separately, Zelensky said Ukraine is preparing to buy 25 Patriot air defence systems.
items.content: Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelensky said he is ready to join Vladimir Putin and Donald Trump in Budapest if he is invited to the Russian and US leaders’ summit. The meeting has been set up by Trump in a bid to broker peace in Ukraine and could be held in a matter of weeks. Separately, Zelensky said Ukraine is preparing to buy 25 Patriot air defence systems.

items.standfirst: President Donald Trump insisted that the ceasefire in Gaza was still in place after Israel launched strikes in the enclave and traded accusations with Hamas that each side had violated the fragile truce he helped broker."We wanna make sure that it's going to be very peaceful with Hamas," Trump told reporters onboard Air Force One late Sunday after Israel carried out a wave of strikes in response to what it said were a series of Hamas attacks on Israeli forces in the southern Gaza city of Rafah

items.title: Live: US envoys Witkoff and Kushner return to Israel as border crossing reopens for aid
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump’s special envoy Steve Witkoff and his son-in-law Jared Kushner have returned to Israel amid the fragile ceasefire in Gaza. The just over week-old truce faced its first real test this weekend as Israel launched a number of deadly strikes on the enclave after two of its soldiers were killed in an attack it blamed on Hamas. Israel temporarily prevented aid from reaching the territory but reopened at least one border crossing on Monday morning.
items.content: US President Donald Trump’s special envoy Steve Witkoff and his son-in-law Jared Kushner have returned to Israel amid the fragile ceasefire in Gaza. The just over week-old truce faced its first real test this weekend as Israel launched a number of deadly strikes on the enclave after two of its soldiers were killed in an attack it blamed on Hamas. Israel temporarily prevented aid from reaching the territory but reopened at least one border crossing on Monday morning.

items.title: Israel launches retaliatory strikes in Gaza after saying Hamas killed 2 soldiers
items.standfirst: An Israeli security official said the transfer of aid into the territory is halted "until further notice," the first major test of the ceasefire.
items.content: An Israeli security official said the transfer of aid into the territory is halted "until further notice," the first major test of the ceasefire.

items.title: Israel resumes Gaza ceasefire
items.standfirst: Gaza’s fragile ceasefire faced a major test Sunday after Israeli strikes killed militants in response to the deaths of two soldiers. Aid deliveries were briefly halted but are set to resume Monday, according to an Israeli official. The military later said it was once again enforcing the ceasefire. Over a week into the US-brokered truce, President Trump confirmed it remains in effect

items.title: London hosts major sumo wrestling tournament, second ever outside of Japan
items.standfirst: A major sumo wrestling tournament was held outside of Japan this weekend for only the second time ever. Ramy Inocencio reports from London's Royal Albert Hall.
items.content: A major sumo wrestling tournament was held outside of Japan this weekend for only the second time ever. Ramy Inocencio reports from London's Royal Albert Hall.

items.title: Israel and Hamas trade accusations of ceasefire violations
items.standfirst: Israel launched airstrikes on southern Gaza early Sunday in the first major test of its ceasefire with Hamas, as the two sides traded accusations of significant breaches of the deal brokered by President Trump. NBC News’ Daniele Hamamdjian reports.
items.content: Israel launched airstrikes on southern Gaza early Sunday in the first major test of its ceasefire with Hamas, as the two sides traded accusations of significant breaches of the deal brokered by President Trump. NBC News’ Daniele Hamamdjian reports.

items.title: Scramble to shore up ceasefire as Israel hits Gaza with deadly raids
items.standfirst: IDF says attack followed Hamas forces killing two soldiers, but both sides say they are committed to ceasefireIsrael launched waves of lethal airstrikes on Sunday and cut off all aid into Gaza “until further notice” after a reported attack by Hamas, in escalations that marked the most serious threat so far to the increasingly fragile ceasefire in the devastated territory.Two Israeli soldiers, including an officer, were killed in the Hamas attack. Palestinian officials said dozens died in the retaliatory airstrikes. Continue reading...
items.content: IDF says attack followed Hamas forces killing two soldiers, but both sides say they are committed to ceasefireIsrael launched waves of lethal airstrikes on Sunday and cut off all aid into Gaza “until further notice” after a reported attack by Hamas, in escalations that marked the most serious threat so far to the increasingly fragile ceasefire in the devastated territory.Two Israeli soldiers, including an officer, were killed in the Hamas attack. Palestinian officials said dozens died in the retaliatory airstrikes. Continue reading...

items.title: Israel says it is resuming enforcement of Gaza ceasefire after accusing Hamas of violations
items.standfirst: The Israeli military said Sunday it had resumed enforcing a ceasefire in Gaza after carrying out dozens of strikes on Hamas targets earlier in the day and accusing the group of targeting its troops. Hamas denied the accusations, with one official accusing Israel of fabricating "pretexts" to resume the war.
items.content: The Israeli military said Sunday it had resumed enforcing a ceasefire in Gaza after carrying out dozens of strikes on Hamas targets earlier in the day and accusing the group of targeting its troops. Hamas denied the accusations, with one official accusing Israel of fabricating "pretexts" to resume the war.

clusters.title: Two killed as cargo plane skids off Hong Kong runway
clusters.neutral_headline: Cargo Plane Skids Off Hong Kong Runway, Killing Two

items.title: Two killed as cargo plane skids off Hong Kong runway
items.standfirst: The accident is one of the deadliest at Hong Kong International Airport since the hub opened in 1998.
items.content: The accident is one of the deadliest at Hong Kong International Airport since the hub opened in 1998.

items.title: Two dead after cargo plane skids off Hong Kong runway into sea
items.standfirst: The Emirates cargo flight hit a vehicle on the ground after it landed at the international airport.
items.content: The Emirates cargo flight hit a vehicle on the ground after it landed at the international airport.

items.title: Hong Kong: two killed after cargo plane veers off runway into sea while landing
items.standfirst: Authorities say plane collided with patrol vehicle, taking it with it as it ditched in seaTwo people were killed in Hong Kong after a cargo plane hit a ground vehicle while trying to land and skidded off the runway into the sea.The Emirates flight had flown in to Hong Kong international airport from Dubai at about 4am on Monday when it veered off the runway and crashed through a fence, according to airport officials. It then collided with the security patrol car, taking the vehicle with it as it ditched into the sea. Continue reading...
items.content: Authorities say plane collided with patrol vehicle, taking it with it as it ditched in seaTwo people were killed in Hong Kong after a cargo plane hit a ground vehicle while trying to land and skidded off the runway into the sea.The Emirates flight had flown in to Hong Kong international airport from Dubai at about 4am on Monday when it veered off the runway and crashed through a fence, according to airport officials. It then collided with the security patrol car, taking the vehicle with it as it ditched into the sea. Continue reading...

items.title: Cargo plane skids off Hong Kong runway into sea
items.standfirst: A cargo plane arriving from Dubai ran off the runway and into the sea while landing at Hong Kong International Airport.
items.content: A cargo plane arriving from Dubai ran off the runway and into the sea while landing at Hong Kong International Airport.

items.title: Cargo plane veers off Hong Kong runway and into sea, killing two
items.standfirst: At least two people have been killed after a cargo plane suddenly took an abrupt turn upon landing and veered off the runway and hit the car they were sitting in. The plane then skidded into the sea, dragging the car with it. Officials said the runway conditions were next to perfect at the time of the incident and that the plane had made no distress call prior. The cause of the accident is still unclear.
items.content: At least two people have been killed after a cargo plane suddenly took an abrupt turn upon landing and veered off the runway and hit the car they were sitting in. The plane then skidded into the sea, dragging the car with it. Officials said the runway conditions were next to perfect at the time of the incident and that the plane had made no distress call prior. The cause of the accident is still unclear.

items.title: Two ground staff killed at Hong Kong airport after cargo plane skids off runway
items.standfirst: Two people died when a cargo plane coming from Dubai struck a ground service vehicle and skidded off the runway and into the sea at Hong Kong International Airport.
items.content: Two people died when a cargo plane coming from Dubai struck a ground service vehicle and skidded off the runway and into the sea at Hong Kong International Airport.

items.title: Two ground staff killed at Hong Kong airport after cargo plane and vehicle go into the sea
items.standfirst: Two people were killed Monday when a cargo plane skidded off a runway at Hong Kong International Airport after it struck a ground service vehicle, sending both the plane and the vehicle into the sea, officials said.
items.content: Two people were killed Monday when a cargo plane skidded off a runway at Hong Kong International Airport after it struck a ground service vehicle, sending both the plane and the vehicle into the sea, officials said.

items.title: Video shows cargo plane in the sea after Hong Kong crash which killed two people
items.standfirst: A cargo plane has skidded off the runway into the sea while landing at Hong Kong International Airport, killing two people on the ground.
items.content: A cargo plane has skidded off the runway into the sea while landing at Hong Kong International Airport, killing two people on the ground.

ai_summary: A cargo plane arriving from Dubai ran off the runway into the sea.
The plane hit a ground vehicle, killing two ground staff.
The accident is one of the deadliest at Hong Kong International Airport.
The plane veered off the runway after landing.
Runway conditions were reportedly perfect at the time.

clusters.title: Bolivia turns page on Socialist era, elects great-nephew of 1952 revolution leader
clusters.neutral_headline: Bolivia Elects Center-Right President, Ending Socialist Rule

items.title: Bolivia turns page on Socialist era, elects great-nephew of 1952 revolution leader
items.standfirst: Bolivians elected Rodrigo Paz as president, selecting the center-right senator and economist to address the country's worst economic crisis in 40 years. Paz, 58, campaigned on slashing public spending, especially on fuel subsidies, and vowed a "capitalism for all" approach to economic reform in a marked shift from the preceding two decades of socialist government. The president-elect, who will assume office on November 8, has promised that his governance style will be one of "consensus," as he hopes to gain public trust in a divided society. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, Eve Irvine welcomes Dr. John Crabtree, Research Associate at the Latin American Centre in the University of Oxford.
items.content: Bolivians elected Rodrigo Paz as president, selecting the center-right senator and economist to address the country's worst economic crisis in 40 years. Paz, 58, campaigned on slashing public spending, especially on fuel subsidies, and vowed a "capitalism for all" approach to economic reform in a marked shift from the preceding two decades of socialist government. The president-elect, who will assume office on November 8, has promised that his governance style will be one of "consensus," as he hopes to gain public trust in a divided society. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, Eve Irvine welcomes Dr. John Crabtree, Research Associate at the Latin American Centre in the University of Oxford.

items.title: Bolivia elects center-right president, ending two decades of socialism
items.standfirst: Bolivia elected pro-business center-right senator Rodrigo Paz as president on Sunday, ending 20 years of socialist rule. With nearly all votes counted, Paz won 54.6% against former interim president Jorge "Tuto" Quiroga's 45.4%, according to the Supreme Electoral Tribunal. The country remains in deep economic crisis.
items.content: Bolivia elected pro-business center-right senator Rodrigo Paz as president on Sunday, ending 20 years of socialist rule. With nearly all votes counted, Paz won 54.6% against former interim president Jorge "Tuto" Quiroga's 45.4%, according to the Supreme Electoral Tribunal. The country remains in deep economic crisis.

items.title: Bolivia elects centrist Rodrigo Paz, ending decades of socialist rule

items.content: Rodrigo Paz's win shows Bolivians want change, but he faces economic challenges after almost 20 years of socialist rule.

items.title: Centrist Rodrigo Paz wins Bolivia's presidential runoff, topping right-wing rival

items.content: Centrist senator Rodrigo Paz won Bolivia's presidency with 54% of the vote, ending 20 years of rule by the Movement Toward Socialism party amid economic turmoil.(Image credit: Natacha Pisarenko)

items.content: Paz, the son of a former president, promises 'capitalism for all' as election ends 20 years of socialist government.

items.title: Rodrigo Paz Pereira wins Bolivia’s presidential runoff marking a new shift to the right
items.standfirst: Sunday’s election marked the first time since 2005 that no candidate from Evo Morales’ Mas party was on the ballotCentre-right senator Rodrigo Paz Pereira, 58, won Bolivia’s presidential runoff on Sunday and will be the country’s next president, marking a shift to the right after nearly 20 years of dominance by the leftist Movimiento al Socialismo (Mas) party.With just over 97% of ballots counted in the electoral court’s “preliminary” tally, Paz Pereira secured 54.6% of the vote, while rightwing former president Jorge “Tuto” Quiroga received 45.4%. Continue reading...
items.content: Sunday’s election marked the first time since 2005 that no candidate from Evo Morales’ Mas party was on the ballotCentre-right senator Rodrigo Paz Pereira, 58, won Bolivia’s presidential runoff on Sunday and will be the country’s next president, marking a shift to the right after nearly 20 years of dominance by the leftist Movimiento al Socialismo (Mas) party.With just over 97% of ballots counted in the electoral court’s “preliminary” tally, Paz Pereira secured 54.6% of the vote, while rightwing former president Jorge “Tuto” Quiroga received 45.4%. Continue reading...

items.title: Centrist outsider Rodrigo Paz wins Bolivian presidency, ending socialist rule
items.standfirst: Centrist senator Rodrigo Paz won Bolivia’s presidential election on Sunday, preliminary results showed, in a surprise victory that ended 20 years of dominance by the left-wing Movement Toward Socialism party. His win reflected growing anger over the country’s deepening economic crisis, fuel shortages and soaring inflation.
items.content: Centrist senator Rodrigo Paz won Bolivia’s presidential election on Sunday, preliminary results showed, in a surprise victory that ended 20 years of dominance by the left-wing Movement Toward Socialism party. His win reflected growing anger over the country’s deepening economic crisis, fuel shortages and soaring inflation.

items.title: Bolivia to vote in presidential runoff that will turn it to the right
items.standfirst: End of almost two decades of leftist rule could revive ‘war on drugs’ in change of approach to coca cultivationBolivians go to the polls on Sunday in an election that, whatever the result, will mark a complete shift to the right after nearly 20 years under the rule of the leftist Movimiento al Socialismo (Mas).The country’s first-ever presidential runoff pits the centre-right senator Rodrigo Paz Pereira, 58, who won the first round in August, against the rightwing former president Jorge “Tuto” Quiroga, 65, who in recent weeks has overtaken Paz Pereira in the polls. Continue reading...
items.content: End of almost two decades of leftist rule could revive ‘war on drugs’ in change of approach to coca cultivationBolivians go to the polls on Sunday in an election that, whatever the result, will mark a complete shift to the right after nearly 20 years under the rule of the leftist Movimiento al Socialismo (Mas).The country’s first-ever presidential runoff pits the centre-right senator Rodrigo Paz Pereira, 58, who won the first round in August, against the rightwing former president Jorge “Tuto” Quiroga, 65, who in recent weeks has overtaken Paz Pereira in the polls. Continue reading...

Paz won with 54% of the vote in the presidential runoff.
Paz campaigned on reducing public spending and economic reform.
Paz faces economic challenges after almost 20 years of socialist rule.
Paz is the son of a former president.

Continue reading...

items.title: Which jewels were stolen from the Louvre Museum?
items.standfirst: During Sunday’s daring heist at the Louvre Museum, thieves stole eight pieces of priceless 19th-century French crown jewellery, including emerald and sapphire sets once worn by royals such as Empress Marie-Louise and Queen Marie-Amélie. A ninth item — Empress Eugénie’s emerald-studded crown — was dropped and found damaged near the museum.
items.content: During Sunday’s daring heist at the Louvre Museum, thieves stole eight pieces of priceless 19th-century French crown jewellery, including emerald and sapphire sets once worn by royals such as Empress Marie-Louise and Queen Marie-Amélie. A ninth item — Empress Eugénie’s emerald-studded crown — was dropped and found damaged near the museum.

items.title: Thieves stage daring daytime jewel heist at Louvre
items.standfirst: Armed with power tools and a plan straight out of a heist movie, three or four thieves broke into the Louvre on Sunday and made off with royal jewels once worn by France’s queens and empresses, officials told NBC News. NBC News’ Molly Hunter reports from Paris.
items.content: Armed with power tools and a plan straight out of a heist movie, three or four thieves broke into the Louvre on Sunday and made off with royal jewels once worn by France’s queens and empresses, officials told NBC News. NBC News’ Molly Hunter reports from Paris.

clusters.title: US-Colombia drug trade feud escalates
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Cuts Aid to Colombia, Calls Leader "Drug Dealer

items.title: US-Colombia drug trade feud escalates
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump said on Sunday night he would raise tariffs on Colombia and stop all payments to the country after US military strikes on boats accused of carrying drugs. Trump also called Colombian President Gustavo Petro an "illegal drug leader", which Petro and his government strongly rejected. The tensions come as the US is also involved in a conflict with Venezuela in the region. FRANCE 24's Philip Turle has the analysis.
items.content: US President Donald Trump said on Sunday night he would raise tariffs on Colombia and stop all payments to the country after US military strikes on boats accused of carrying drugs. Trump also called Colombian President Gustavo Petro an "illegal drug leader", which Petro and his government strongly rejected. The tensions come as the US is also involved in a conflict with Venezuela in the region. FRANCE 24's Philip Turle has the analysis.

items.title: Trump announces tariffs and an end to U.S. aid to Colombia amid clash over drug trade

items.content: The U.S. will slash assistance to Colombia and enact tariffs on its exports because the country's leader, Gustavo Petro, "does nothing to stop" drug production, President Donald Trump said Sunday.(Image credit: Fernando Vergara)

items.title: Trump calls Colombia president ‘illegal drug dealer’ as US says it hit another ship
items.standfirst: Trump vows to cut US funding as Pete Hegseth says US hit Colombian rebel group vessel and ‘three terrorists killed’Donald Trump on Sunday accused Colombia’s president, Gustavo Petro, of being an “illegal drug dealer” and threatened to immediately cut US funding to the country, as a Republican senator said the US would soon announce “major tariffs” on the country.It comes after the US defense secretary confirmed in a social media post an attack on a vessel associated with a Colombian leftist rebel group. Pete Hegseth said “three terrorists were killed” in the operation, which was “conducted in international waters”. Continue reading...
items.content: Trump vows to cut US funding as Pete Hegseth says US hit Colombian rebel group vessel and ‘three terrorists killed’Donald Trump on Sunday accused Colombia’s president, Gustavo Petro, of being an “illegal drug dealer” and threatened to immediately cut US funding to the country, as a Republican senator said the US would soon announce “major tariffs” on the country.It comes after the US defense secretary confirmed in a social media post an attack on a vessel associated with a Colombian leftist rebel group. Pete Hegseth said “three terrorists were killed” in the operation, which was “conducted in international waters”. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Trump will cut aid to Colombia and impose tariffs.

items.title: Gucci owner Kering to sell beauty division to L’Oréal for €4bn
items.standfirst: New chief executive Luca de Meo aims to bring down debt burden and refocus on core fashion businessBusiness live – latest updatesThe Gucci owner, Kering, is selling its beauty division to L’Oréal for €4bn (£3.5bn), as its new chief executive, Luca de Meo, seeks to turn around the French luxury company.The deal will give the French beauty group L’Oréal Kering’s fragrance line Creed, which was founded in 1760. The deal also includes rights to develop fragrance and beauty products under Kering’s fashion labels Gucci, Bottega Veneta and Balenciaga under a 50-year exclusive licence. Continue reading...
items.content: New chief executive Luca de Meo aims to bring down debt burden and refocus on core fashion businessBusiness live – latest updatesThe Gucci owner, Kering, is selling its beauty division to L’Oréal for €4bn (£3.5bn), as its new chief executive, Luca de Meo, seeks to turn around the French luxury company.The deal will give the French beauty group L’Oréal Kering’s fragrance line Creed, which was founded in 1760. The deal also includes rights to develop fragrance and beauty products under Kering’s fashion labels Gucci, Bottega Veneta and Balenciaga under a 50-year exclusive licence. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: The demonstrations against the US president - which Republicans had called "hate-America rallies" - were boisterous but peaceful.
items.content: The demonstrations against the US president - which Republicans had called "hate-America rallies" - were boisterous but peaceful.

items.title: Watch: Aerials show thousands attending No Kings protests across the US
items.standfirst: Protesters took to the streets of American cities to demonstrate against President Trump's policies.
items.content: Protesters took to the streets of American cities to demonstrate against President Trump's policies.

ai_summary: Crowds gathered in cities across the US for "No Kings" protests.
Protests were held to express anger over President Trump's policies.
Millions of Americans participated in the anti-Trump demonstrations.
The protests were described as boisterous but peaceful.
Republicans labeled the protests as "hate-America rallies".

clusters.title: Artillery shrapnel hits vehicles on California highway during Marines celebration
clusters.neutral_headline: Artillery shrapnel hits vehicles on California highway

items.title: Artillery shrapnel hits vehicles on California highway during Marines celebration
items.standfirst: California Governor Gavin Newsom had shut down the freeway, even though White House officials said it was safe.
items.content: California Governor Gavin Newsom had shut down the freeway, even though White House officials said it was safe.

items.title: Artillery shell exploded prematurely over California freeway during marines celebration
items.standfirst: Shrapnel fragments rained on vehicles parked on Interstate 5 including highway patrol and JD Vance’s detailA live artillery shell exploded prematurely during a marines live-fire demonstration that launched over a southern California freeway in celebration of the military branch’s 250th anniversary, raining shrapnel down on a California Highway Patrol vehicle and a motorcycle that was part of JD Vance’s detail, according to a police report.The New York Times reported that fragments that fell from the 155mm shell landed on vehicles parked on a ramp on Interstate 5 – a major artery through southern California – which governor Gavin Newsom had ordered closed after learning that military officials had no plans to close the freeway. Continue reading...
items.content: Shrapnel fragments rained on vehicles parked on Interstate 5 including highway patrol and JD Vance’s detailA live artillery shell exploded prematurely during a marines live-fire demonstration that launched over a southern California freeway in celebration of the military branch’s 250th anniversary, raining shrapnel down on a California Highway Patrol vehicle and a motorcycle that was part of JD Vance’s detail, according to a police report.The New York Times reported that fragments that fell from the 155mm shell landed on vehicles parked on a ramp on Interstate 5 – a major artery through southern California – which governor Gavin Newsom had ordered closed after learning that military officials had no plans to close the freeway. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Shrapnel from a live artillery shell hit vehicles on a California highway.
The incident occurred during a Marines celebration.
The freeway was closed by the governor after the incident.
The shell exploded prematurely during a live-fire demonstration.
Shrapnel landed on a California Highway Patrol vehicle.

items.content: A football derby in Tel Aviv between Hapoel and Maccabi has been cancelled after "violent riots", according to Israeli police.

ai_summary: The Tel Aviv football derby was canceled due to "violent riots".
Police reported the throwing of smoke grenades and pyrotechnic devices.
The match was between Maccabi and Hapoel.
One club described the police response as "brutal violence".
The derby was called off before the scheduled kick-off.

items.content: The report in a British newspaper follows Buckingham Palace's announcement on Friday that Andrew agreed to relinquish use of the Duke of York and other remaining royal titles.

items.title: Police look into reports Prince Andrew sought information on Jeffrey Epstein accuser

items.content: LONDON — Britain’s Metropolitan Police are “actively looking into” reports that Prince Andrew tried to obtain personal information about his accuser Virginia Giuffre, a spokesperson for the force told NBC News on Sunday

items.content: Britain's Prince Andrew will not use his royal titles any longer, he said in a statement released by Buckingham Palace on Friday.
